## Introduction

External flow—where fluid flows over and around an object—is common in engineering: aircraft wings, heat sinks, pipelines in wind.

## Flat Plate

### Laminar Flow (Re < 5×10⁵)

$$\text{Nu}_x = 0.332 \, \text{Re}_x^{1/2} \, \text{Pr}^{1/3}$$

$$\overline{\text{Nu}}_L = 0.664 \, \text{Re}_L^{1/2} \, \text{Pr}^{1/3}$$

### Turbulent Flow (Re > 5×10⁵)

$$\overline{\text{Nu}}_L = 0.037 \, \text{Re}_L^{4/5} \, \text{Pr}^{1/3}$$

```{python}
import numpy as np

def nusselt_flat_plate(Re: float, Pr: float, turbulent: bool = False) -> float:
    """Average Nusselt number for flow over a flat plate."""
    if turbulent:
        return 0.037 * Re**0.8 * Pr**(1/3)
    else:
        return 0.664 * Re**0.5 * Pr**(1/3)

# Example
Re = 1e5
Pr = 0.71  # Air
Nu = nusselt_flat_plate(Re, Pr, turbulent=False)
print(f"Nu = {Nu:.1f}")
```

## Key Takeaways
- Flat plate: Nu ∝ Re^0.5 (laminar) or Re^0.8 (turbulent)
- Cylinders and spheres: more complex due to separation
- Always check Re to determine flow regime
